scene_parts.animation_planning: Start with blank screen, then show a Gaussian curve appearing from left in center of frame. Curve should be large enough to be clearly visible but not touch edges of frame.
scene_parts.animation_details: Initially, the screen is blank. Then, a standard Gaussian curve animates in, appearing from left and taking center position of frame. The curve is light blue. The curve should be approximately 6 units wide and 4 units tall, centered at the origin.
scene_parts.audio_text: Let's explore the Gaussian distribution, also known as the normal distribution.

scene_parts.animation_planning: Add labels for mean (μ) at center top of curve, x-axis as random variable below curve, and y-axis as probability density on left side. Show dashed line for mean. Keep safe distance between text and curve.
scene_parts.animation_details: Label the mean with a white dashed vertical line at the peak of the curve, extending down to the x-axis. Add the symbol 'μ' in white above the curve at the top of this line. Label the x-axis as 'Random Variable' in white, positioned below the x-axis. Label the y-axis as 'Probability Density' in white, positioned to the left of the y-axis. The x-axis label should be about 2 units below origin, and y-axis label should be about 2 units left of the origin.
scene_parts.audio_text: It's a cornerstone of statistics and probability, and you'll find it almost everywhere in the real world.

scenes.scene_style: Dark background. Gaussian curve in light blue. Labels and axes in white. Mean represented by a dashed vertical line.

scene_parts.animation_planning: Highlight left side of curve from mean to tail. Change its color to light green to show symmetry. Change it back to original blue.
scene_parts.animation_details: Highlight the left side of the Gaussian curve by changing its color to light green. The left side starts from the mean (μ) and extends to the left tail. After a brief moment, revert the color back to the original light blue.
scene_parts.audio_text: One key feature of the Gaussian distribution is its symmetry.

scene_parts.animation_planning: Highlight right side of the curve from mean to tail. Change its color to light red to demonstrate symmetry. Change it back to original blue.
scene_parts.animation_details: Highlight the right side of the Gaussian curve by changing its color to light red. The right side starts from the mean (μ) and extends to the right tail. After a brief moment, revert the color back to the original light blue.
scene_parts.audio_text: The curve is perfectly symmetrical around its mean. In fact, the mean, median, and mode are all equal and lie right at the center.

scenes.scene_style: Dark background. Gaussian curve in light blue. Highlight left side in light green and right side in light red momentarily. Labels and axes in white.

scene_parts.animation_planning: Show standard Gaussian curve at center of frame.
scene_parts.animation_details: Display the standard Gaussian curve in light blue, centered on the screen. The curve should be same as previous scene.
scene_parts.audio_text: The spread of the data is determined by the standard deviation.

scene_parts.animation_planning: Show a taller and narrower curve in yellow along with standard curve. Make it clear that yellow curve has smaller standard deviation. Scale down the curves a bit to fit them together nicely.
scene_parts.animation_details: Introduce a second Gaussian curve in yellow, positioned at the same center as the original curve. scene_parts.audio_text: A smaller standard deviation results in a tall, narrow curve.

scene_parts.animation_planning: Show wider and flatter curve in purple along with other two curves. Clearly indicate that purple curve has larger standard deviation. Scale down all three curves further if needed.
scene_parts.animation_details: Introduce a third Gaussian curve in purple, also centered at the same point. This curve is wider and flatter, representing a larger standard deviation. Label this curve as 'Larger σ' in white. Make all three curves about 3 units wide and 2 units tall.
scene_parts.audio_text: while a larger one gives us a wide, flat curve.

scenes.scene_style: Dark background. Standard curve in light blue, smaller standard deviation curve in yellow, and larger standard deviation curve in purple. Labels in white.

scene_parts.animation_planning: Show Gaussian PDF formula: f(x | μ, σ) = (1 / (σ * sqrt(2π))) * exp(-(x - μ)^2 / (2σ^2)) at center of frame. Scale it down to fit frame properly.
scene_parts.animation_details: Display the Gaussian PDF formula at the center of the screen: 'f(x | μ, σ) = (1 / (σ * sqrt(2π))) * exp(-(x - μ)^2 / (2σ^2))'. The formula is in white. The formula should be scaled down to about 8 units wide and 1 unit tall.
scene_parts.audio_text: Mathematically, the Gaussian distribution is described by its probability density function, or PDF.

scene_parts.animation_planning: Highlight (1 / (σ * sqrt(2π))) in green.
scene_parts.animation_details: Highlight the scaling factor part of the formula, '(1 / (σ * sqrt(2π)))', in green.
scene_parts.audio_text: This formula has two main parts: a scaling factor

scene_parts.animation_planning: Highlight exp(-(x - μ)^2 / (2σ^2)) in orange.
scene_parts.animation_details: Highlight the exponential part of the formula, 'exp(-(x - μ)^2 / (2σ^2))', in orange.
scene_parts.audio_text: and an exponential part that gives the curve its shape.
